titlestmt.titleproper: Ford Foundation records, Rights and Social Justice, Office Files of Lynn Walker Huntley
A Guide to the Ford Foundation records, Rights and Social Justice, Office Files of Lynn Walker Huntley FA692

profiledesc.creation: This finding aid was produced using ArchivesSpace on 2020-03-27 19:13:47 -0400.

did.unittitle: Ford Foundation records, Rights and Social Justice, Office Files of Lynn Walker Huntley

physdesc.extent: 8 Paige boxes, 5 LGL size Hollinger boxes, and 5 LTR size Hollinger boxes

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: The collection arrangement is as follows:

processinfo.head: Processing Information
processinfo.p: Level 1 Minimal Processing was conducted for the first accession of material to establish basic intellectual and physical control of the material and assess immediate preservation and conservation needs. Material remains as received, in original folders and storage boxes.

Level 3 Standard Processing was completed for the 2018:064 accession of Lynn Walker Huntley office files. This material was processed by Darren Young in September 2018. Records were added to the end of Series 1. Subject Files.

Level 3 Standard Processing was completed for a box of the Huntley Office Files that was included in a different accession of unrelated Ford Foundation records (Accession 2018:063 of the Ford Foundation records, EMAC, MAC, Office Files of John P. Santos collection) by Darren Young in November 2018. Accession 2018:063 was transferred at the same time as 2018:064. Material from this box was added to where the Accession 2018:064 records finished in Series 1.

userestrict.head: Conditions Governing Use note
userestrict.p: Completion of a use agreement is required prior to providing scholarly access. See RAC Head of Reference (or applicable designee) for details. Ford Foundation holds title, copyright and literary rights in the collection, in so far as it holds them. The Rockefeller Archive Center has authority to grant permission to cite and publish material from the collection for scholarly purposes. Permission to publish extensive excerpts, or material in its entirety, will be referred to the Ford Foundation.

acqinfo.head: Immediate Source of Acquisition note
acqinfo.p: Ford Foundation archive was deposited at RAC in 2011. Ford Foundation records, correspondence, reports, program files and officers papers were transferred to, and accessioned by, RAC beginning in 2011. Accessions continue as necessary.

Second group of Lynn Walker Huntely's office files was transferred to the RAC by the Ford Foundation in 2018 and was ingested by the RAC as Accession 2018:064. This accession was incorporated into the collection during processing in 2018.

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation note
prefercite.p: Information regarding the Rockefeller Archive Center's preferred elements and forms of citation can be found at http://www.rockarch.org/research/citations.php

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Contains correspondence, consultant files, program reviews, meeting records and subject files.

Collection consists of more than one accession of Lynn Walker Huntley office files ingested by the RAC over the years. An accession processed in 2018 consisted of a group of subject files regarding the Ford Foundation's work with the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People (NAACP) and was added to the end of the Subject Files Series in order to reconstitute the relationship between the materials. Another box of Huntley office files was added from a different accession of unrelated Ford Foundation records (Accession 2018:063 of the Ford Foundation records, EMAC, MAC, Office Files of John P. Santos collection) later in 2018. It was determined during the processing of that accession that the materials were connected to the Huntley subject files that the RAC ingested in 2018, and thus the box was incorporated into Huntley's collection.

accessrestrict.head: Conditions Governing Access
accessrestrict.p: Open for research. Brittle or damaged items are available at the discretion of RAC.

bioghist.head: Biographical / Historical
bioghist.p: The Ford Foundation was chartered by Henry and Edsel Ford in 1936 "to receive and administer funds for scientific, educational and charitable purposes, all for the public welfare", and initially served the Ford family's charitable interests in the Detroit area. Following the deaths of Edsel Ford (1943) and Henry Ford (1947), the Foundation was propelled to the forefront of philanthropy as the largest American foundation in terms of both endowment and yearly expenditures, and with an international scope to its major program areas.

During the Foundation's first twenty years its major programs were in international economic development, primary and higher education, educational and public broadcasting, behavioral sciences, civil liberties, urban development, fine arts and the humanities. The Ford Foundation also partnered with the Rockefeller Foundation in supporting agricultural development in South America, Africa, and Southeast Asia. Since the 1970s, the Foundation has also pioneered programs in women's rights, energy policy, micro-financing in under-developed countries, establishing human rights groups, and improving international HIV/AIDS education.

bioghist.head: Biographical / Historical
bioghist.p: Lynn Walker Huntley (1945-2015) came to the Ford Foundation in 1982 to work as a Program Officer focusing on civil rights programs. She would eventually become Director of the Rights and Social Justice Program until she left the foundation in 1995. She served briefly as a consultant for Ford after leaving her position as Rights and Social Justice Director and was tasked with monitoring the foundation's grants to the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People (NAACP).

Prior to her time at Ford, Huntley worked as a lawyer for the NAACP Legal Defense and Education Fund (LDF) in the 1970s. While with the LDF, she was part of the legal team that managed the Furman v. Georgia legal case. The U.S. Supreme Court's decision on the case in 1972 resulted in a temporary suspension of the death penalty within the whole nation. Huntley would later serve at the U.S. Department of Justice Civil Rights Division.

During her time at Ford, Huntley helped obtain funding for the U.S. Civil Rights Movement documentary Eyes on the Prize and started the African American Church Initiative. After leaving Ford, she joined the Southern Education Foundation, and in 2002, became president of that foundation.

otherfindaid.head: Other Finding Aids
otherfindaid.p: Finding aids concerning the office files of other Ford Foundation officers in the Rights and Social Justice Program as well as the subsequent Human Rights and International Cooperation Unit of the Peace and Social Justice include:

FA590 Ford Foundation records, Peace and Social Justice Program (PSJ), Human Rights and International Cooperation (HRIC), Office Files of Alan Jenkins
FA613 Ford Foundation records, Peace and Social Justice Program (PSJ), Human Rights and International Cooperation (HRIC), Office Files of Cristina Eguizabal

did.unittitle: Subject Files

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Series consists of the subject files Lynn Walker Huntley created to document her work in the Ford Foundation's Rights and Social Justice Program.

It contains a significant number of files concerning the Foundation's support of the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People (NAACP). These records originate from a later accession of Huntley's office files that was processed in 2018. They mostly regard the financial, administrative, and legal troubles the NAACP experienced during the early and mid-1990s, the monitoring and disbursement of the Ford Foundation's funding to the organization and its Special Contribution Fund (SCF), the foundation's support for the NAACP's financial and strategic planning initiatives, the controversies surrounding the foundation's backing of the NAACP during this time period, some of the social justice and civil rights issues the NAACP focused on during the 1980s and 1990s, and questions concerning the NAACP's continued relevancy in advocating for racial equality and empowerment of racial minorities amidst its series of crises.

Some of the subject files appear to have been created and maintained by Huntley's successor as Director of the Rights and Social Justice Program, Mary E. McClymont, as well as by other staff members of the Human Rights and International Cooperation Unit of the Peace and Social Justice Program which replaced the Rights and Social Justice Program during the foundation's reorganization in 1996. This may indicate that the offices for these programs continued to use and add to the subject files created during Huntley's term as Director of the Rights and Social Justice Program even after Huntley's departure from Ford.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Original folder was unlabeled. File contains documents related to the Council on Foundations, the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People (NAACP), and the First Nations Development Institute.

did.unittitle: Correspondence

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Chief correspondents of the Ford Foundation Rights and Social Justice Program (and later Peace and Social Justice Program) within the file include Lynn Walker Huntley, Anthony Romero, and Mary McClymont.

The correspondence regards public housing and housing desegregation, domestic violence, minority rights, women's rights, African American churches, the care and maintenance of the Reverend Jesse Jackson papers, and the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People (NAACP).

did.unittitle: Legal - Women's rights reserve request

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: File regards a reserve request for a capacity building initiative involving flagship civil rights and women's rights organizations.

did.unittitle: Miscellaneous - John Hopkins University

processinfo.head: Processing Information
processinfo.p: Original folder was grouped with the preceding Legal Women's rights reserve request (Box 17, Folder 79 and Box 17, Folders 80-81). However, the content of the file had no relation to those files. It was determined during processing that the folder was likely misplaced from the subsequent group of miscellaneous files. Description reflects that association.
